papers.abstract: Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI) analyzes complex biological samples such as tissues. It simultaneously characterizes the ions present in the tissue in the form of mass spectra, and the spatial distribution of the ions across the tissue in the form of ion images. Unsupervised clustering of ion images facilitates the interpretation in the spectral domain, by identifying groups of ions with similar spatial distributions. Unfortunately, many current methods for clustering ion images ignore the spatial features of the images, and are therefore unable to learn these features for clustering purposes. Alternative methods extract spatial features using deep neural networks pre-trained on natural image tasks; however, this is often inadequate since ion images are substantially noisier than natural images. We contribute a deep clustering approach for ion images that accounts for both spatial contextual features and noise. In evaluations on a simulated dataset and on four experimental datasets of different tissue types, the proposed method grouped ions from the same source into a same cluster more frequently than existing methods. We further demonstrated that using ion image clustering as a pre-processing step facilitated the interpretation of a subsequent spatial segmentation as compared to using either all the ions or one ion at a time. As a result, the proposed approach facilitated the interpretability of MSI data in both the spectral domain and the spatial domain.

events.Text: Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI) analyzes complex biological samples such as tissues. It simultaneously characterizes the ions present in the tissue in the form of mass spectra, and the spatial distribution of the ions across the tissue in the form of ion images. Unsupervised clustering of ion images facilitates the interpretation in the spectral domain, by identifying groups of ions with similar spatial distributions. Unfortunately, many current methods for clustering ion images ignore the spatial features of the images, and are therefore unable to learn these features for clustering purposes. Alternative methods extract spatial features using deep neural networks pre-trained on natural image tasks; however, this is often inadequate since ion images are substantially noisier than natural images.

Primary Object: complex biological samples such as tissues

Context: It simultaneously characterizes the ions present in the tissue in the form of mass spectra
and the spatial distribution of the ions across the tissue in the form of ion images
Method: deep neural networks pre-trained on natural image tasks
Results: facilitates the interpretation in the spectral domain by identifying groups of ions with similar spatial distributions

alternative methods extract spatial features using deep neural networks
Challenge: current methods...are unable to learn these features for clustering purposes
ion images are substantially noisier than natural images
Implications: progress has been made in improving interpretation
potential for future applications in bioimaging
Contradictions: disagreements with existing knowledge about ion image processing
methods that focus solely on spectral data versus those incorporating spatial-spectral integration

events.Text: We contribute a deep clustering approach for ion images that accounts for both spatial contextual features and noise.

In evaluations on a simulated dataset and on four experimental datasets of different tissue types, the proposed method grouped ions from the same source into a same cluster more frequently than existing methods. We further demonstrated that using ion image clustering as a pre-processing step facilitated the interpretation of a subsequent spatial segmentation as compared to using either all the ions or one ion at a time.
events.Main Action: grouped ions from the same source into a same cluster more frequently than existing methods

Context: evaluations on a simulated dataset and on four experimental datasets of different tissue types
Purpose: to compare the proposed method with existing methods and demonstrate its effectiveness

Analysis: using ion image clustering as a pre-processing step facilitated the interpretation of a subsequent spatial segmentation as compared to using either all the ions or one ion at a time

events.Text: As a result, the proposed approach facilitated the interpretability of MSI data in both the spectral domain and the spatial domain.

papers.abstract: Phecodes are widely used and easily adapted phenotypes based on International Classification of Diseases codes. The current version of phecodes (v1.2) was designed primarily to study common/complex diseases diagnosed in adults; however, there are numerous limitations in the codes and their structure. Here, we present phecodeX, an expanded version of phecodes with a revised structure and 1,761 new codes. PhecodeX adds granularity to phenotypes in key disease domains that are under-represented in the current phecode structure — including infectious disease, pregnancy, congenital anomalies, and neonatology — and is a more robust representation of the medical phenome for global use in discovery research.

events.Text: Phecodes are widely used and easily adapted phenotypes based on International Classification of Diseases codes. The current version of phecodes (v1.2) was designed primarily to study common/complex diseases diagnosed in adults; however, there are numerous limitations in the codes and their structure.

Here, we present phecodeX, an expanded version of phecodes with a revised structure and 1,761 new codes. PhecodeX adds granularity to phenotypes in key disease domains that are under-represented in the current phecode structure — including infectious disease, pregnancy, congenital anomalies, and neonatology — and is a more robust representation of the medical phenome for global use in discovery research.

Context: under-represented in the current phecode structure -- including infectious disease
Purpose: a more robust representation of the medical phenome for global use in discovery research
Method: an expanded version of phecodes with a revised structure and 1,761 new codes
Results: adds granularity to phenotypes in key disease domains
Analysis: This indicates that besides expanding the code system, it refines specific aspects
Challenge: ensuring the new codes cover all necessary areas without overlap
Implications: more accurate research across various domains globally
